title: Oris’ Big Crown ProPilot X Calibre 115 Lifts Off With A Next-Gen Pilot Design
text:
Text size

Oris zeroes in on the essence of mechanical watchmaking with the 44mm titanium Big Crown ProPilot X Calibre 115, a contemporary evolution of its popular pilot model.

Offering a window on how a mechanical movement operates, the skeletonized Big Crown ProPilot X Calibre 115 ($7,200 on strap, and $7,600 on titanium bracelet) dispenses with the dial to put the focus on the dynamic gears, wheels, and bridges that make up the intricate architecture of the hand-wound Calibre 115, a direct descendant of the Caliber 110 movement developed to mark the brand’s 110th anniversary in 2010.

“Previously, we had this incredible movement, but no one could really see how it worked,” Oris’ Chief Operating Officer Beat Fischli said in a release. “Skeletonization is such an exciting form. You really get to see all the details. And you get to show what you can do.”

One particularly distinguishing characteristic is the oversize barrel, which delivers the watch’s remarkable 10-day power reserve, indicated by the brand’s patented non-linear gauge at 3 o’clock.

The Calibre 115 movement. Oris

“Normally, the mainspring is hidden, even in many skeletonized watches, but we felt we had to show it because so much of the story of the watch is in its 10-day power reserve,” Fischli said. Not only can you see the barrel, you can watch the coil of the mainspring tighten as you wind the watch to its maximum energy capacity.

Senior Product Design Engineer Lukas Bühlmann was tasked with propelling the brand’s pilot watches into the next generation. Accordingly, Bühlmann took inspiration from aviation and architecture to come up with a design that would transcend fashion while projecting timeless style.

“The idea behind the watch started with the movement, and we gave this a strong architectural look,” Bühlmann said in the press materials. “The skeletonized barrel draws your eye first and then the bridges, and then you start seeing the detail in the wheels. The case is more like a stealth plane. There’s an exciting interplay between the movement and the static elements.”

$7,200 on strap. Oris

Bühlmann and his team also got rid of the Arabic numerals you would typically see on an aviation watch. Other contemporary details, such as the facets on the case, the integrated bracelet, the angular crown protectors, and the design of the bridges complement each other to make a sporty yet technical statement.

Underscoring that modern aesthetic, the skeletonized bridges are matte grey with sharp, clean edges, instead of traditional beveled borders. The grooved bezel evokes the blades of a turbine while simultaneously echoing the collection’s signature big crown.

“It’s certainly not a conventional pilot’s watch,” Bühlmann said. “But the aviation DNA is still there in the details. We used titanium for the case, for example, because it’s very light. What really makes this a pilot’s watch is its technical look. Technology is the driving force behind aviation today.”
description: The watch offers a window on how a mechanical movement operates
